[1975]
The Woman's Club of Avon Park
Avon Park, Florida
Nov-16th
Dear Mrs Moore,
I received your check and
will turn it over to our Treasurer
this next week at our Bd. meeting.
I am sure the Bd. of the
Womens Club, will appreciate your
contribution in memory of your
mother, who was so active in
this organization.
I am enclosing a clipping from 
our news paper that you might 
be interested in, so many things 
have come to light in this centennial 
year.
Sincerely yours
Elizabeth Thompson
Corresponding secretary

January 22-27
Flagler Beach, Fla.
Dear Mrs. Walden - 
So sorry not to have seen you when I was over that way just before Christmas. But we only stayed a few days and I was hurry trying to collect some money which no one seemed to have. We have had and are still having much bad luck and as no one over here has any money it makes it very depressing.
We had a very nice Christmas though, which helped to make a break. We spent

it in Jacksonville and it is the first time I've had Hollis home in seven years so you know we had a nice time. I've had another little visit up there since too. I am so thin every one spoke of it when I was over there.
Things do seem to be trying to be better than they were but it all seems very slow. I know you all must have been terribly busy helping all those poor people. What a blow that must have been to Sebring when Mr Leo E. died.

I have my dog but no cat now.
My pups is really loads of company.
We often go down on the 
beach and play together - I am
less than a block from the water.
There are no trees here so we
do not have any birds and the
soil is queer so no flowers.
It is really a very desolate sort of a place.  I read a great deal and
sew a whole lot. I used to do pine
needle work but haven't for a long
time. Of course I am more ac-
quainted with the people here and
can get out more. Every one is so
far away from every one else tho'. 
I am so glad you are able to be
back in club work this year and
wish I could be back there as I en-
joyed all our good times together.
There have been fifteen planes over 
me this morning and I always
have the lovely ocean to watch so 
I hope I can get to feeling better.
Love and best wishes to you
and your mother.
Lovingly,
Helen Baker

448 Lincoln Avenue, Eau Claire,
Wisconsin, July 24, 1927.
Dear Mrs. Walden, The Avon Park 
newspapers brought me
the news of the death of your 
mother. I am very sorry for 
you all. She seemed to have 
so great vitality and so won-
derful a constitution, that I
hoped she might recover and
be with you yet many years.

I am glad that you had
others of your family with
you.
I am sending this to Highlands
but you may be in Glen Ellyn
with your daughter. I should
be glad to hear from you, and
shall be glad to see you again
in Avon Park, if I return in the
fall. I bought a return ticket
this year.
I have spent much of the time 
in the garden this summer.
We lost our brother-in-law. Our
youngest sister's husband.

He died the 3rd of July; I was with
Laura four days of that week. Her
daughter and family will be with her
through August. She had much to do
after his illness of a month. I wish
that she would go South with me.
Please give my kindest regards and 
sympathy to all members of your family,
Affectionately yours,
Elizabeth Bangs

Banta Bros. Bank 
Capital and Surplus $40,000.00
Business Established 1889
Bank Incorporated 1920
Lowpoint, Ill
Frank D. Banta, President / A.L. Banta, Vice President / A.D. Banta, Second Vice President / Wm. C Stauter, Cashier / Merle L. Kunkel, Assistant Cashier

7/14 - 27

Mrs May Waldon
Avon Park Florida.
My dear May - I notice by the last
weeks Metamora Harald an account of the
death of your mother. I wish to express to
you my most sincere sympathies in this
time of your deepest of all sorrows. There
is none who passes from this world who
are so dear as mother. We can ever and
and always do what we can for mother
while she lives, but we never can pay for
what she has done for us. Of course you
haveing been with her during so much
of your life, you will miss her more. But
I hope you will cheer up as much as you 
can, and be consoled with the Christian
hope that while your father & mother can
no more come to you, that you will at 
some time be able to go to them. This
is a wonderful hope for the Christian to
have. May you do not know how happy
it makes me feel to think that we had you
and your mother to dinner with us the one
Sunday when you and she were visiting

Banta Bros. Bank 
Capital and Surplus $40,000.00
Business Established 1889
Bank Incorporated 1920
Lowpoint, Ill
Frank D. Banta, President / A.L. Banta, Vice President / A.D. Banta, Second Vice President / Wm. C Stauter, Cashier / Merle L. Kunkel, Assistant Cashier

in Illinois. I only regret you could not
have been with us more times afterward.
I always like the old time Metamora folks.
We have had our sorrows here too. Our 
brother John passed away very suddenly one
week ago this evening. He worked all day
hard till late in the evening and came to the
house sick and died soon after. The passing
of poor John breaks up the family circle
of we four boys who have been so closely 
allied to gether at this place for more than
thirty-years.
What arrangements will you make for
the future? Will you still remain at
Avon Park? When you come to Illinois
don't forget to come and see us. You
are always welcome.
Hoping this finds you well and that
I may hear from you often I remain
with sympathies.
Yours A.L. Banta

[Ms. Barshell, described 4/3/56]
Wed. 7 a.m
QT.1. 359X Stacy
West Palm Beach. Fla.
Feb. 15. 1956
Dear Mrs. Walden;
When I wrote to you Sunday I said I
would write again and let you know
how I came out at the Welfare Office.
I was interviewed and am waiting for
the "visiter" to come and look things
over. They say it will take at least sixty
days to tabulate everything. I don't know
what the check will be but, like you, I
don't expect it to be very much.
Another problem was settled Monday but
it's too wordy to tell in detail. Luise 
and Mac wanted the front half of my
land to build a home. She feels it's too
much for Mac to keep up those payments
The only way out was to buy a cheaper
lot and build a cheaper house, he was 
to build it in his spare time. They wanted
to give me $300.00 and fence in the whole place
and Fred was to donate his time to the fence,
which he was perfectly willing to do since 
I need the fence badly. Now came the hitch.
I asked Luise when I'd get the fence, she
said very firmly - that I can't say, once
[on side] I hav'nt played my records since I got my T.V. have almost forgotten the names of some.

2/
Mac gets started on the house he'll
be very busy for a long time. "I said
I can't hand the deed over, not knowing
when I'll get anything for it, She said
"I thought it was worth that much to
you to have no living near by." To which
I replied -  It's been my experience that
people won't do the decent thing once
they get ahead of me. They don't unless I'm
in a position to make them do it. "She
said - we'll just call the whole thing off."
Mac used to have schemes to get a hold of
that other property before I sold it, I'm
sure this was another scheme. He told
people he had rental property and
telephone calls came asking "Mrs. McFarland
what they asked for that seven room house
on the corner, they think they're so smart - 
but - seems to me they could be a little subtle
about the matter.
I'm feeding Mrs. Ellis's rabbit and chickens
while they are away to visit their daughter.
She has about thirty, snow white, clean
and sweet looking, I still have only two. She
has 14 hens, they've laid 9 eggs 3 days in
succession, jinx is jumping against the
door, howling to get in. I give him his

3.
breakfast outside and then let him in
for awhile. He's still in that puppy age so 
he chews on things and pulls things down
It's really something raising a puppy.
This morning I put bread crumbs
and water out and soon had your kinds
of birds around. Most people don't like
grackles but they're very interesting to
me. If they get a crust on stable bread
they dip it in the water so they can break
it up. I also had wren and killdeer.
The mockingbird keeps to himself in
the backyard. He has his own feeding 
station there.
Luise tells me that Wiggles got over
his injuries. For months he held his
head to one side. She thought it was because
he had the injured eye but even that has im-
proved. He has a special place on the sec-
tional couch. It's the one facing T.V. you
can imagine he has competition. If it's one
of the family he simply attacks and they
have to move. But one day a stranger came
and sat down where Wiggles wanted to sleep.
He paced back and forth giving the man
his one-sided look. Finally he jumped on
the couch and, gently, clawed the man's arm.

4
The man didn't know what it was
all about so he wanted to pet Wiggles.
Then Wiggles got rough, climbed up on his
shoulder and attacked in real earnest.
Luise tries to keep him in nights since
he was hurt so badly but he hates that
yellow tom-cat with a passion and
just wants to get out and beat him up - 
you know, just get the best of him. Once Ginger
loves Wiggles and Luise discovered that
Ginger will fight for him so she lets
them both out at the same time. Of course
there's the danger of a car hitting one of
them but Wiggles just must have a round
with that hateful cat lives across the road.
I'm afraid this letter sounds like a re-
port from an animal institute. Must go
and attend to Mrs. Ellis's chores.
Tell Cora hello from me. I hope
Larry kept on improving. I sent Fred
to buy a lawn sprinkler and Mrs. Edwards
gave me one they weren't using. It works all 
right. I over-did things yesterday so intend
to take it easy today. After attending to Mrs.
Ellis's animals I did a lot of yardwork, mostly
hoeing weeds, then put out a wash and a little
house-work so went to bed early - no T.V. last night - 
I'll probably sit up late tonight. Love Nettie
[on side] Are you enjoying your second player? Tell me about some of your records. Hope you have Rubensteins fine dance.

RT.1 359X Stacy
West Palm Beach. Fla.
April 18th 1956
Dear Mrs. Walden;
I was so happy to get your letter.
When I don't hear from you in a week
or two I begin to worry. First I'm afraid
you are ill, then I begin to fear my
letters aren't very interesting. That
you are getting a little tired of answering
them. (my inferiority complex still plagues
me)
Now for some good news. The Welfare 
worker has been to see me and tells me
my first check will be here May 15th. The
others will come on the twenty third of the
month. She has no idea what the amount
will be. She is a fine woman and told me
several things I was entitled to which 
will make things easier for me.
We had a fine rain April 10th. I had
hoped for a rainy day so I could do some
sewing but that was the day Luise took
me shopping for Esthers birthday gift.

She got me the next day to attend the
party, 7 or 8 little boys and girls of the 
neighborhood. They all had lovely manners
and Esther made a very thoughtful hostess.
She is trying hard to overcome that boisterous
tom-boy nature she once told me she could
not help because she was born that way.
Recently she came in trembling because she
stepped on a snake and I let it get away, I said - don't cry, it
was harmless snake. She said - it could
get married to a poison snake and raise
poison snakes."
I have three lovely tomatoe plants
that somehow survived the freeze. They 
are full of bloom and all sizes of toma-
toes. I will have to shade them soon or
the sun will destroy them.
The six young rabbits are doing fine.
They are so cute, all six of them sitting around
their dish nibbling grain, and wriggling their
little noses. Esther and Buster had a baby
rabbit given to them. Ginger thinks it's her

3.
responsibility. She washes it and fights 
any dog or cat that comes near it. One
night it got out of it's cage and outside 
the fence. Ginger came to the bedroom
window and woke Luise up. First she led
her to the cage to show her the rabbit wasn't
there, then she led her to the hole under the
fence to show her where the rabbit had
escaped Luise said the bunny was wet
with saliva which made her think Ginger 
had carried it back to the cade at least
once befor it got outside the fence.
Luise and Mac will move out here
May 1st. If they hav'nt sold their house
by that time they will rent it. They cer-
tainly have a bad case of wanting to live in
the country, and I don't see why except
that the children can develop better in
the country. Buster is a mechanic already
and Esther loves animals and plants so
I may get some enjoyment watching
them do the things I've always wanted to do.

Fred and Maxine are almost sure to get the
job in Carolina, don't know the location,
but what worries them is that they will have
cabin duty nights, that means Fred will have
to sleep at the boys camp and Maxine at 
the girls camp. They won't be able to keep
Gloria, Mrs. Edwards will keep her six weeks
out of the eight. I'll have her the two weeks
while Mrs. Edwards takes her vacation.
Fred wanted me to come to Carolina for 
my vacation so I told him there is no
place on earth I'd rather be than right
here. This is a perfect vacation every day in
the year.

At Home,
Nov. 12.
Dear Katharine,
At last!
Yes, at last! I have written to your dear mother, and told her of you, and your two fine boys, and how happy you made my visits, and of Mr. Moore's kindly presence at one of my Sunday calls. A very lovely and heart-warming family, with the

dear, gracious, bright, beaming, gentle mother, and the tall handsome father, and the two engaging fine boys! Blessings on you and yours!
Faithfully, 
James Vila Blake

Chicago, June 28, 1915
My dear Katharine,
I have your note - this morning -  & wish to come at your call with all my heart. But I am compelled to beg you [as ?] another date, if kindly you will. I am under long engagement to visit my beloved old friends the Badgers

family at Winfield on Wednesday. Sorry for the interference.
Affectionately,
J.V. Blake

At Home
Nov. 12. 1924
Dear Mrs Walden,
I have had you constantly in mind, to write you a wee note, just to say that I am the same to you and for I'm in thought that I always was and especially to tell you of my Sunday visits to Katherine at Glen Ellyn. Once I went on purpose, and had lunch with her and made a

long call, delightful to me. Katherine received me so affectionately and with such easy grace, and was so pretty to my eyes with her fine bright hair and delicate features, that it all was notable pleasure. Then her two boys! Fine and happy they seem. A lovely little family. Maxine (I believe that is the name, but my mem-

-ory is poor for names/ the younger one, was in his first beauty of late baby-good, with his long and curly and soft light hair, and active life. He is a blessed handsome little fellow, a treasure. Too bad that you have not seen him yet! The father and husband came in at one of my calls and looked well, strong and handsome, and was very good

to me. I may hope that the dear and sweet young mother is happy again. Love does not seem so difficult. I wonder that so many make so little out of it. No news of me. You know well my manner of life. I am very hard at work, hoping and trying for 3 or 4 years more, - years to finish my literary plans. To your mother my reverential greeting and to you always and the same true friend,
James Vila Blake.

World Events
125 5th St. NE 

Washington 2DC

This may be my last letter till we get to Florida - prob. late March, 
Xmas Eve.
Dear May - A tremendous and most soul-
satisfying day - nearly 100 letters! It
was 11. 30 pm before I could make myself
stop and get ... breakfast. Have now
just penned and read of keenest pleasure
your comradely letter, so vibrant w/ your
F. A. Blossom

warm and rich personality. How I wish
we were comfortably ensconced chatting
about the I.W.W. our early lives and many
other matters of common interest! Or
swinging like monkeys from tree to tree in
that orange grove of yours. I was brought
up on Jas. Freerman Clark(e)?. But I now don't
claim to be even a Christian. To be a friend
good neighbor and loyal fellow worker is all I can manage.
We should concentrate on The Enemy - Capitalism.
As ever, Fred Blossom
[transcription note: name of Jas. Freerman Clark(e) is likely James Freeman Clarke]

Oct 18/ - midnight
Dear May,
I know you won't mind
a pencilled note in reply to your
welcome letter read this a.m. I only
wish I had read all those "thought letters"
"beef and pork" -  wait till I tell Ed
Garlits and Scott Nearing on you! They
don't even eat eggs or drink milk,
but I don't go that far. I don't balk
at a little meat in my chop suey. 
and I occasionally eat chicken but I like
best fruit, nuts, cereals, (in moderation).
and above all raw-vegetable salads in
quantity. And what strength and endurance I have! It's miraculous,
at 74 and never very robust.
I was very glad to send a copy of W E? to Margret Campbell.
[On side] No - put peace stamps all over my envelope - but why on the back?

So glad to hear such splendid things
of Mr XYZ. I want very much to
meet him soon after I get to Seffner.
Is he a businessman? In what line?
In what manner, may I ask? are
you of "The Chas. H Kerr family."? I
have high regard for that pub house.
As in tramps, I got my training in
the I.W.W. We had little respect for
them. They were no help in anyway and
interested only in getting by.
I'd like to suggest - if you possibly
can - 2 or 3 additions to your list of
periodicals. I'll mail you samples.
I wish I'd replace Mr. XYZ as your angel
(and you be my cherub?) but I'm barely getting
by on my $20.00 a week. This jib entails
various incidental outlays.
And now goodnight dear friend.
Yrs, J.A.B.
[on side] I'm awaiting the Women's Report (from Berlin).

[printed] To put a worthwhile truth in circulation is a good day's work
World Events Clearinghouse
East Palatka, Florida
Dec 31st - 4 a.m
Dear May,
For a full week I've been
trying to get a chance to write to you,
but many things have prevented - 
a series of four visitors of special
importance to our work, all sorts of
holiday doings for the old folk here,
(As for me, 40 years ago I resolved to
boycott the Xmas - New Year's mass
insanity 100% and I've heroically stuck
to that resolution and many friends are
secretly grateful to me - "There's one
person we don't have to send something
to.") - also some too-long-delayed
"spring" planting etc.
So I got out of bed early this
am especially to get this off to you and
to say, primo, that we we beg you by all
means to come and see us, as you said
[printed] A man's judgement is no better than his information

you might, not only do we want
to see you but we want you to meet
a very interesting and charming person
of our generation and way of thinking
who is staying w/ us just now - 
Minerva Rautenstrauch, widow of
one of the outstanding men at
Columbia University, whose lectures
were so popular they had to be given
in the auditorium - no classroom
large enough!
Seconds, to thank you most
warmly for the basket of beautiful
oranges and grapefruits, Bertie is allergic alas, to most

citrus fruits but

navel oranges are mild and so I am 
kind of saving them for her - except
as to a dozen of the biggest which we 
sent to dear Mrs. Stern, in Washington - 
you met her here. Mrs. R - (vide supra)
is passionately devoted to grapefruit - 
as for me I devour all citrus fruits.
Do write us that (and when) you are coming.
Our love to you, Yrs,
Fred Blossom
[on side] Many of "our" folk affix the NATO stamps upside down - you can guess why.

Scott Nearing
Jamaica, Vermont
"World Events" 
125 Fifth Street, N.E.

Washington 2, D.C. [checkmark]

Dec. 14, 1951
Dear May Walden,
For some weeks I've
had your letter of Oct 24th in my active
file, hoping for a chance to answer it, but
the "must" work has piled in in such a 
gratifying stream that it left me not even
10 or 15 minutes free time.
Now here comes your 
most welcome order and check for $400-
the first response to that blue circular and
we take it as a good omen. I have just
wrapped the books and added various items
which I hope you will find interesting.
Going back to your letter -
call me anything you like that shows
friendliness except the diminutive ending
in -die or -dy because that was what 
they called me in my earliest days and seems
hardly suited to a white-haired man who
will be 74 next month.

I echoed of course, your condemnation of
the World War III issue of "Kollier's." I obtained a 
ringing denunciation of it fe - crossed out by
the Chicago American Soviet Friendship
Council and distributed 100 copies in outgoing
pkgs (sorry I haven't one to send you.) I
doubt if the publishers are pleased w/ the
results of their special issues.
I was keenly interested in your connection of C.H. Kerr and Co, 
and also in what you
told me of Mr. XYZ, (now in Orlando). I 
do want to meet him soon after we get to
Florida and ask his business advice. I
shall have to work out some way to earn
a little w/ part time work, leaving most 
of my time free for World Events.
Answering your question, I believe the
C.H. Kerr Co. is still in business and carrying much
the same line as in "ye olden tyme."
When we meet lets talk about the I.W.W., 
of which I was an active member and which 
is just about my ideal of a labor union.
Our removal to Florida will have to be put
off a month or two - too much preparatory
work to be done and current work ties me down
just now. And now to snatch a little sleep,
forgive me if I write little until we get moved and
settled. Cordially yours,
Fred Blossom

[typed] We pay any price for war, but we expect peace to come down like a dove / and land on our shoulder for nothing. Is it worth so little to us?
Jan 13, 1952
May, my dear
You came very close
to the date, I keep it to myself
because I'm agin all such conventions - in fact nearly all
conventions and especially formalities
such as Xmas, birthdays, bread and
butter letters, hats (male), pajamas
(or nightshirts) etc, anyhow it's
friendly of you to remember OMB
(Old Man Blossom) but go and sin
no more sister. "Skip all that," 
cried the Bellman in haste. "We're
out for the Snark i.e. Capitalism and we've no time
to waste "(How's your "Alice"?)
And it was good of you, too, to
send me that article on the Klan.
And the envelope prepared to save my time.
[on left side] Don't put much stock in libraries. They thank you and put your gift in the 
trash basket. Most librarians are craven creatures "yellow as hell" I was 
25 years a librarian. Garlits has twice sent oranges but they go fast as
I share them w/ 10 or 12 active helpers.
[on right side] Your half acre sounds inviting because of the choice company.
[typed] This stationery may be purchased from World Events, 125 Fifth St., N.E., Washington 2, D.C.--75 sheets
and 50 envelopes for $1.00. The proceeds will be used to further Scott Nearing's work for world peace.

It is disturbing to know that the
Klan is active in Tampa but
we'll have to take our chances.
Do keep that [k]clipping. I hope you
have the series. (I'm a librarian
by profession - one of my four or five
professions.)
I see little use in opposing UMT - 
unless one's interest doesn't go deeper. Those of
us who understand that things will
only go from bad to worse until we
get rid of Capitalism should pour
all our resources of time thought and
money into educational work along
that line! "Capitalism is the enemy - 
Socialism is the only cure."
I've long heard of "The Bible Unmasked"
but I'm narrow minded (perhaps) also as
to "Christ-killing." So many atheists,
freethinkers and nationalists are rabid
flag wavers (Joseph Lewis, for example -
I tangled w/ him once at his forum in N.Y.
on his patriotism and red baiting) and beneficiaries
of the capitalist system. Blame my I.W.W. training. I've stuck to the class struggle. 
[on side] You should also send a 10 cent air letter for the (free) Prague News
Letter, Stalinova and Prague XII, Czechoslovakia. Ask especially for
their issue of mid-December. The lead article on Xmas is so superb
I've airmailed for 250 copies.
[on top, upside down] It's 2:30 am - an 18-hour day and I must get rested
for another tomorrow. I must read the proof and make
up the page dummy for WE 73 a creative task I enjoy.
Good night, dear. Why are you so far away? F.A.B.

4 am 3/21/54
Darling May,
We love you for
that concern over us, but there
is nothg to be done but to keep
calm & continue our work
for a better world even more
actively than ever. The only
salvation for all of us - &
civilization - lies in the coming
of socialism - even to these
Benighted States of America.
I am becoming "possessed" - 
obsessed - by the fast-growing
conviction that those of us who
have "seen the vision" of what
socialism will mean to the
world are almost criminally

negligent if we don't steadfastly
refuse any longer to be diverted
by side issues and throw all our
thought, energy and resources
into a systematic, patient
long-time educational movement
to teach the US folk- (who
imprudently arrogate to themselves
the designation of Americans - as
if Canada, Guatemala, & Chile 
were in Africa) 1. the evils of
Capitalism & 2. the advantages of
Socialism. I am gradually
working toward a plan for us all
to do just that.
So glad you may come to visit us.
All we need is time to reply as to whether
there wd be a room for you. This week
for us, we are crowded to the doorsills. 
But do come when you feel equal to it
w/ our love, Fred Blossom

8/20/54
Dear May,
Your letter came while
we were away on a tiring business
trip - a real estate taxes tangle, 
but all OK now.
No, no word from "the enemy" &
no trouble as a result of his "dirty
work" - none, as far as we know
Your local trouble seems un-
believable but many folk are
having similar experiences these
days. I can well understand
how you need the N.G. If you
will permit me to do so, I'd love to
express to you a sealed pkg of "asstd lit."
I wd ship it as from The Wysong
Rest Home and the P.O. wd have
nothing to do w/ it. All legal
stuff, of course. R.S.V.P  and say "OK."
I keep thinking how dreadfully
lost & lonesome it must seem to
be cut off from all news from & of
our side. Why not come & visit
us for a week & rest & read & read?

I feel sure "they" wouldn't bother you for any
lit coming to you - such action against anyone
your age wd arouse people & they don't want that.
I can't stomach "Time." We receive "Newsweek" - 
it's "not bad. " Why not try it instead?
Yes, "we" sure are making gains & rather fast
of late. "Red" China has achieved front-rank
standing by her conduct at Geneva. It looks as if
EDC were doomed. No. Africa is waking up.
England insists on trading w/ USSR/ & Japan w/ China.
The brutal action in Guatemala has stirred public
sentiment in Latin America. But I expect things 
to get tougher in this bedevilled country in the desperate
(long) final stand of Capitalism by its resort to fascism.
Radio has just this minute reported that USA has
furnished "parts" for Chiang Kai-shek to construct 200
landing assault craft for an invasion of the mainland - 
that all the Nationalists needed was these craft
"& U.S. support" (vis the 7th Fleet?). Now they have both.
Let's hope the mad venture ends as did Indo-China.
As for news from "Bellamy Farms" the most important item is

that we have definitely put this place

on the market for sale. Both Bertie & I have worked
for over 50 years & we want to ease up - & to have more
time to work for Socialism & to travel about a bit.
(One trip we want to take is to see you & to take a look at
that concentration camp down there, where some of us
may soon be "boarders.") We find this place too
large to maintain unless we have at least 8 patients
& that throws too much day & night care on Bertie.
We cut the number to four but that means no
margin for the living help, so I'll have to be goatherd
& farmhand when a young friend now w/ us goes
back to college in a week or two. Which will leave me 
too little time for "subversive" activities.

I am more and more obsessed w/ the thought that virtually nothing
is being done to educate the US public
as to the truth about socialism, to
counteract the NAM & C of C. propaganda
for "free" enterprise. And I'm losing interest
steadily in providing entertainment &
intrstg reading for those who are already
of our way of thinking. We need, of course,
such means of intercommunication
as Natl Gdn & Ms. Rev? but at present
we are leaving the big field wide open to
the enemy. While we spend our efforts on
lecturing & writing for our own people!
How do you feel about this? Right now
I have hereabouts 15 or 20 folk
ripe to read & think about 1. the
evils of "free enterprise" & 2. the
advantages of capitalism, but nothing to give them.
Your PCM dollar - please tell 
me OK to use it for a 6-mo. trial
sub. for you to R. Palme Dutt's
"Labour Monthly" from London.
S.N. thinks highly of it & so do I -
You wd get a great deal from it.
Must close & get to work. Our love
to you - How about coming to see us?
Yours, fab

12/29/30(midnt)/54
Dear May,
Bertie & I have been 
thinking a lot about a really
exciting plan which has
rich possibilities. We have
talked it over w/ friends from
Clearwater, Clermont, New
Smyrna Beach, St Petersburg
(these were four congenial
couples here for the Thksgvg
weekend & what a feast of
friendly discussion we had! - 
& how hard it was to resume

want to tell you all about it &

what suggestions you may

part in writing another chapter

(and perhaps a more sensible &
successful one) in the history of
communal experiments in USA.
But we now can't both be

(our very capable maid leaves at
2 p.m.). So we want very much
that you shd - & "pronto" - "hop
a bus" & come up here & pay us a
good long unhurried visit we
have a very pleasant room
waiting for you & you will meet
a very lovely woman, Minerva 
Rautenstrauch, widow of one of the

She knows everybody & will be delighted to meet CHK's widow.

Till then - & after -

1/7/55
Dear May,
We are delighted 
that our suggestion of your
coming for a visit met w/ -
such a hearty response.
The visitation holds good
for as long as may be necessary at your end, 
but we hope you may soon be able
to make the needed arrangements. Minerva R. plans to
stay till spring but experience has taught us that "chance
& change are busy ever" & one
never knows what is going to 
happen till it does.
When you do come, leave

enough food at the back
door or at the neighbor's to
keep the cats alive for quite
a while so that you don't have
to hurry back.
If you can do so, let us
know a few days in advance
so that we can arrange for
our very special friends, Ernest
& Maude Collette, to come from
Clermont at the same time, as
we very much want you to
meet them.
There are so many fine folk
in Florida, we have discovered!
It is a shame that they are so 
scattered. - Almost as bad as if
they lived in Kamchatka. If only
we cd all congregate somewhere - 
what a jolly time we'd have!
Yours, Fred Blossom

Sunday Feb. 13/55

Dear May

 We have had to keep you waiting several days for a reply but simply could not get both time & strength together to write. My  days have been over-full partly with helping the Kellys to get settled and find a small store to try their luck once more (clothing, shoes, hats &c esp. for working people) and partly because of Bertie not being in good health

& obliged to spend considerable time in bed - for the first time in fifty years! She was worn out and consequently afflicted w/sundry strange aches

and pains, but is much better today

 And Thursday came your lovely and too generous basket of delicious fruit - which we wanted to thank you for but couldn't because we had on our hands several

hundred lettuce, cabbage, onion, cauliflower & broccoli plants and the beds weren't ready for them. Now that the old folks' home has been given up, we can't treat ourselves to the luxury of a "hired man" so I have to take his place. And after a long day's work on "the farm" one is in no shape for desk work.  It is so cold today, I'm going to seize the
opp. to get off some corresp.

  You ask about the Kelly's - I'll enclose some letters recd from them, which don't return: Other details I'll tell you viva voce, as it is quite possible letters are opened en route these days. But I doubt seriously

crossed out:if that you know them - but you will soon.

 There's a swell transition to the most immediately important matter - your coming to visit us. Minerva R.'s other sons in St. Petersburg but will be back by Feb 22nd - if

she doesn't catch cold or something. As she may be leaving us in March we are most anxious to have you & the Collettes come soon after Wash - B'day - will you & they 
please get together on this & let us know when to expect you? -  Have you a phone? just in case...

 Those delicious King oranges again! Nowhere else have I seen them. Once more our heartfelt thanks.
 Bertie joins me in love & in the hope we shall see you soon.
 Yours,
  Fred Blossom

8/5/55

Dear May

 Your dear little note, w/its ingenious device for a reply is another example of the need for us who share the same ideas & ideals to get closer together. We spend months & months like lonely oases in an arid desert of uninteresting "white trash" and we hunger for the companionship of some folk w/whom enjoyable exchange of ideas & information wd be possible. A very few times each year we manage to get maybe 1/2 doz congenial folk to gather here & it's always such a treat that we start wondering again if it wd not be possible to get a

small & very select group to come & form a tiny colony here. Lord knows, w/our 10 acres there's room enough!  One advantage that appeals to me more & more - the nearness of true friends to help meet any emergency such as we old folks must expect now & then.

 Bertie is, on the whole, somewhat better but has real ups & downs. Summer heat has always been very hard on her & now more so than ever, but we have air-conditioned the inside room & when she "feels the heat" she goes into "the deep freeze" & comes out refreshed & ready to carry on.
 She just had a wonderful trip to D.C, N.H. & NY to attend a 6-day seminar by Scott Nearing. Later in the fall we hope to take a long-delayed "wedding trip" to her native

Tennessee &c.

 Now I must turn to letters less fun to write, but important. I reckon I have over 200 piled up on desk, table & chairs.
 Our most affectionate greetings to you. Come & spend awhile w/us any time you feel so inclined. Yours,  Fred Blossom

Do you grow papayas?  We are trying to but our 100 or so none doing so well, will probably all freeze to death this winter, alas!

10/21/55
Dear May

 Just got a note from Helen Nearing, asking us to fwd to you the galley pfs of their new book. I'm mailing the pkg at once, adding some items from our "stock", among them a copy of Carl Marzani's "We Can Be Friends." Don't return anything. The Marzani bk - we recd a free gift of 60 copies w/the request that we distribute them gratis.

Could you "place" 2 or 3 more copies? (Free)

 I included a copy of the new monthly newspaper "The Southerner", pub in Dalton, Ga., edited by that gifted proletarian poet Don West & sponsored & backed by the

Church of God...!  We are lvg here Sunday to go to Dalton to look over their setup - the church is strongly pro-union & pro-coop enterprises, & is being ferociously attached by the Vets of Foreign Wars, the local papers &c  We'd like to have a hand in a battle like that.

 We're sick & tired of wasting our lives in a community that is socially inert & possibly dead. If we cd sell this place, we might move to Dalton - or to N.Y. We can do nothing here worthwhile.
 Novr 7 Bertie goes to a hospital in "Jax" for the first of 2 operations on her feet - fallen arches &c which if left alone, wd soon make a cripple of her. she hopes to be home (& on crutches) in a week's time.
 I wish to gawd you didn't live so g.d. far away. This is no way for us folk to spend our lives. We did congregate somewhere & enjoy congenial company.   Our love to you
               Fred Blossom

Bertie Blossom

Thanksgiving Day '56
Dear May -

 So glad to have a nice letter from you - we too enjoyed your & Berthas visit with us. So nice to have such a pleasant break in this daily grind - But "Praise the lord & pass

the ammunition" the end is in sight - we are expecting the new owner to arrive today with first truck load - more to come about Dec, 1 to 15

Hysong Rest Home                                  2
East Palatka  Florida
our little cottage is waiting for us. gas connected last wk. lights to be turned on next wk. are not having phone - since we plan to leave for D.C. & NY.C soon after Xmas -

 We just now finished getting this big lawn cut & grass raked today - oh: what a relief to feel that this is the last time we'll do that Job!
 We are eating papayas everyday - that is one thing we are sorry to leave - but we have 
     (over)

some coming on at our cottage - won't have to wait very many days after we move in for them to ripen.

 Our orange & grapefruit trees are loaded this yr. we'll take enough to last us thru the holidays.
 When we are settled & before going No. we are planning a So Fla. trip & hope to stop by to see up for a short visit.

I'll write you later.  Hope you are having a very pleasant Thanksgiving Day.

 Love   Bertie & Fred

Sat - Aug 18 - 56 -
Dear May - we have recently returned from a 3 wks vacation in N.E. Ga, mts. It was so nice & cool up there - the heat is severe here - it can't last long - we have not seen you for low these many moons.  we want you to run up for a nice long visit at once - have just written Bertha Howe hope you can come togather, any day, you can arrange to get away
will be o.k. for us.  Just let us know when to expect you. Come as soon as you can & stay as long as possible.

Mrs. Bertie Lee Hysong, R.N.
East Palatka  Florida
Do let us hear from you soon, we are still at the old home place - Just waiting for some one to come by who wants a big house & lawns etc -

 Hoping to see you real soon -  Lovingly

Dear May - 

 We shall have so much to tell you about the success of the Hoxsey Cancer Clinic in Dallas & the Amer Med Assn campaign to exterminate it, & about

our cottage in a Negro section here to which we'll move when we sell this place &  on side: our little farm on a hill in N.E. Ga. & about the two socialist colonies
we have discovered in N.E. Ga. & the upside down: Ku Klux dynamiting of the roadside store of one of them &c. &c. Life is full of interest, we find.  F.A.B.

Tues. 9/11/56
Dear May

 It was a pleasure to know that my "squib" in Soc Progress struck you so favorably and the mental energy shown in your letter is really remarkable. I only

wish I cd. respond in similar manner, but I am forced to confer that my energies are at a rather low ebb just now while my immediate responsibilities are more
pressing than usual so that I wd not have either the time nor the strength to take on anything more.

 The past two years - since we started to close the old folks' home in July 1954 and began wearing series of attempts to work out some way to get some earnings

coming in to replace the modest but sufficient income we had been recvg from the o.f.home - have been hard on both of us,

because of all the attempts we made - which failed - & also because Bertie's operation & long slow convalescence.

 When we get this big place sold & our living simplified, we'll regain the pep we have temporarily lost.
 How keenly we cd sympathize w/you over the mean behavior of those tenants of yours! We had a string of such experiences, till we gave up "landlording."
 Sorry indeed that you don't think you'll be able to make the trip here w/Bertha Howe. But this makes us all the more determined to get down there to see you -

perhaps in Nov. as you suggest

 Meanwhile, our love to you & our hope that life will be kinder to you in future.  You deserve it!
    Affctly yours
      Fred Blossom

3/6/57
Dear Bertha - 
We have been through
a very tough period - hope we are
through, but there seems to be a 
jinx pursuing us. As soon as we
get one problem solved - or
even before - another one drops
from the sky. We are even begin
ning to wonder if there is something
the matter w/ us. Our friends don't
seem to be always tangled up in
other people's troubles the way we have
been since we got our real estate
difficulties under control.
Of course Bertie's sister's illness
was something likely to happen - 
unfortunately - in a sixth [crossed out: quarter] of the 
families in this country, I don't
know whether we had time to write
you that she got steadily worse at
home, so we took her to the Baptist
Hospital in Jax. There her ailment
was at once diagnosed as cancer
of the spine & she was operated on the
very next day, but the surgeon
could only remove part of a spinal

tumor and sew her up, declaring that
any more surgery wd be "useless
cruelty." We moved her to Flagler Hospital in St Augustine

[crossed out: & she died there]

to have her nearer family & friends. She 
died there Feb 24.
Why didn't one of the other hospitals discover the trouble?
When the doctors were insisting that
she was getting better, & the State Road Dept
was about to take over the sister's home for
4 - laning Highway #1, Bertie & I had to arrange for building a

cottage a little to the rear & packing & moving all their belongings.

But the sister never saw the cottage. Her
73-yr-old husband (Bertie's cousin) will
live there.
And now we are tangled up in no 
less than five cases of friends & neighbors
who have turned to us - four in the past
few weeks - to help them out in serious
difficulties. We simply could not in 
common decency, refuse to help them, but
it has entailed a lot of study & investigating & going here & there.
This letter is very disjointed I am
afraid, but is the best I can do tonight.
We are so involved in these matters that
we cannot make any plans ahead,
but they are gradually being solved or settled.
We recd the newspapers you sent & are
holding them for a while in case you need
them. Our love & best wishes & sometime
we'll be free to go about & see our friends.
As ever, Fred Blossom

Dear May,
I am very sorry
not to have been able to
answer your dear letter
more promptly. Recently
our troubles, as Shakespeare
put it, have come "not
single spies but in battalions"
and we have been hard
pressed for time to cope w/ them.
We have tried, these past four
years, to be good neighbors
& [crossed out: frie] good friends to a dozen
or so folk. In a couple of cases,

it has worked well & we are glad
we did what we did, but in others,
loss of job, or sickness or just
plain character deterioration
has led to complications.
However, as an old friend
used to say, "it's not as bad as
losing a leg or a friend." We
are gradually working through
the tangled web.
Where Bertha ever got the idea
that we were planning to drop in

Aug 13/58
Dear May,
We recd your sweet letter
several weeks ago but life has been
crowding us so hard & fast that we have
had to neglect all our dear friends.
This evening the pressure has eased
off a bit & I hasten to write to you.
We have spent 2 days at a "Farm & 
Home Week"at the So. Car. state agricultural college. 
We leave early tomorrow am for our Georgia place
(Rte 3, Clarkesville, Ga)
Very early in June I left Fla. & Bertie
left Ga & DC both headed for NY City
& from there to Amherst, Mass. for the
60th (!) reunion of my college class. 
I had skipped 59 reunions for various
reasons - abroad, out west, down south,
very busy, publishing "World Events" - &
afraid I'd find my Babbitty classmates
less than intrstd in what most interests
in fact, absorbs - me, i.e. Socialism.

We had such a grand time at Amherst that we dream of going again. Only 7 of my class there - most of the others gone to Jesus or unable to move under their own power.
 From Amherst we went to Maine for 8 days w/ Scott & Helen nearing working hard on their farm & evenings helping mail  announcements of their new book - due Oct 14

Then back to NY for 3 weeks or so w/dear old friends in NY & Paterson (where I was once I.W.W. (!) organizer among the silk workers. we were royally treated - on the go every minute. We saw the Russian folk dancers at Madison Sq. Garden! - 18,000 cheering then "to the echo"!

 Then a week in Wash, DC & reunions w/old friends - 14 of them at a "Chinese" supper &c &c.  Thence to Ga. - nearly 36 hours in auto, bus & jitney (our funds very low) Were we tired!  But we jumped in & worked hard for 3 wks to get the weeds &c under control
 How we wish you cd visit us there! Very primitive "conveniences" but a heavenly view and a bracing climate (at least every night).  We'll probably be there till late Oct caring for the fruit & nut trees set out last winter & preparing for more to come next winter.
 There's our story up to date  We hope your knee and your general health are better   our warm love to you from
          Fred & Bertie Blossom

2/10/59 - 
Dear May, So glad you want the
dear little cedar tree. It is waiting
out in our woods for me to come &
get it. I'm going to see if we can't
arrange to ship it "B&B" (ball of
earth & burlap wrapping) via Bertie.
She has been terribly (but not dan-
gerously) sick - flat on her back - 
for 11 days - is a bit better today
but very weak. A complete digestive
breakdown due to months of over-
work (that took 20 lbs off of her!) plus
a minor accident as to diet.
We are marooned 10 miles out of 
town. No faith in doctors. Fasting
homeopathy & hope. (I don't know how to drive)
As soon as she can drive those 450
miles she'll get away for E. Palatka.
I'll have to stay to plant - w/ some help
from a 72 yr old neighbor) 50 Chinese
[note on side:] worst illness of her 74 years on earth

chestnut trees, 3 butternut, 20 figs,
1,000 loblolly pines, 500 poplars &
mulch w/ old sawdust 3000 white
pines set out last winter.
Bertha Howe will, we hope, come to see
Bertie & get all the news & take the cedar
to you. It will do far better that way
than bare roots & parcel post.
Must now to bed. Have picked up
a germ from Bertie but I'm tougher
than she is.
Our love to you,
Fred Blossom
The Gerson book is excellent
You can get it for $3.00 (instead of
$8.50) if to be sent direct to go a library.
That's what we did. Let me know
if you want to present it to yr library.
Wait till you receive some Gerson
articles I'm sending you.
P.S. Alas, the Gerson articles are in Florida.
I'll try to remember to send you a set (4 articles).
I believe he has the answer & that my adopted
daughter hsbd wd be alive today if they had listened to me 
12 years ago.

Monday Feb. 2 / 59
Dear May - 
Sad news as to the
Chinese chestnut tree - see other
side. You'll have to content your
self w/ the nuts we'll send you
from our trees in 4 or 5 years. We
have just (last Friday) had the
field cleared of stumps & bushes &c
w/a bulldozer & we are now digging
56 holes for no less than 56 trees!
How about our sending you the
dear little cedar tree I spoke of?
It is like a little Christmas tree - 
about 3 or 4 feet tall. We had one
at our rest home in East Palatka.
It did well there & gave splendid
shade. (It is an evergreen so it
will not shed its leaves in the fall)
We must take it up anyhow,

as it serves as host to an insect
that was specially created by
"His Majesty" to get into apples.
But you doubtless have no apples
in your section of the country.
Our cedar in E. Palc was a 
real delight. But if you wd
prefer something else, we won't 
be hurt, so answer frankly.
Bertie will go down to Fla. in a 
few days but I shall have to stay
here for 3 or 4 weeks to take care of
various matters. I'll go down by
bus toward the end of Feb.
We were sorry to hear that you
had had a fall. Hope you are
"mending" satisfactorily.
Our love to you,
Fred Blossom

for which I am very grateful tho' that is all for which I feel grateful.   I'm still here in

Chicago  July 14th 1927
My dear friend:

 We were so saddened by reading in the paper of your dear Mother's death. The last news of her was so cheerful and happy

in that wonderful little home! I have often pictured you in it and grateful it fell to your lot to have and enjoy it.  But so sorry she
could not tarry longer to grace and find pleasure in it. We will always cherish her

radiant influence and cheer. You are in my thoughts often these days and wish I might be near you for at such a time words seem to have lost their
meaning. You have met so many trials with heroism; may strength be given you to still "press on"!

 I would like to again see Katherine but to me the trip to Glen Ellyn looms big. Mr. Cleaver and Phyllis both have very little leisure, both in the loop,

Mr. Cleaver doing a little work for the Tribune and Phyllis still with the same Corporation. She is planning for a vacation in Sep. last

year had a delightful though brief stay in the Pennsylvania hills, or mountains(?). Last fall the Company transferred Thane to
Cincinnati; he thought but to accept their offer, although doubt if they like it as well as Chi -

 We are experiencing such decided changes in the weather from such extreme heat to real cool weather and much rain. 

A peculiar year and must be very discouraging to those who get their living from the soil. Our neighbors who settled in New Port Richey
are north again; they liked it there, but business

conditions forced their return for the present at least. We are looking about some what, for a new abode  These buildings are
becoming old & run down and would not be surprised most any time to know they were to be replaced by a hotel or something of that sort.  I want
so much to see you once again; when you find time and strength tell me your plans.

 Our united love and sympathy go to you.
  Always your affectionate friend,
       Minnie Cleaver

July 1, 1927
Dear Aunt & Cousin,

 I hope I am not to late with this letter and so sorry to hear that Aunt is so bad off. I surely am so sorry that I have not wrote before, as I know she
would of enjoyed hearing from us, but let us hope she can enjoy the letter yet.   But May if poor Aunt has to suffer so that is terrible, and she surely will be

well off when she is out of her suffering.  Now I know what it is to stand over the sick as I have took care of Father & Ray since the 13 of Apr. and have not
had my clothes off only 2 nights, and to change in that time.   While Father was here I was up every other night as the Dr. stayed every other night. and took
care of them. but I left my clothes on just the same as at 10 o'clock I would go to bed and the Dr. would say Nellie I might need you before mornng so
that ment be ready.

and poor Grandpa did suffer so he was sick just 2 weeks and 1 day.   on Wed. as he died Thursday. he did not know anyone and Oh! such a noise you could
hear him all over the house. and in the road.    I was so glad our Doctor was here with us all that day and he used 2 hiperdermicks but of no good. then he
stayed with us the night Father died as he died at 7 30 and the Dr. was with Ray. and before the furnal we had to send for him one night at Mohawk as I thought
Ray would not be here when Darwin got back.   And then the Doctor came and stayed the day of the furnal and that night. I can not tell you how good he has
been. he was here The 29 of June and stayed all night. but he had not been here in quite a while before but Rays heart is not very extra and poor blood. he has got so he can sit up 2 hrs. each day.

I don't believe he weighed 75 lbs.   so you see dear Cousin what I have been up against and then to have to help milk and do the chores through the day as Darwin was
teaching.   don't talk about work and trouble.  I have had it all this spring.  It does seem hard for you and us as they are wanted and then to think they are taken when their are some that are in the way and so bad off.     Darwin has a man to help and they are shingling the big red barn expect to finish to day.     I thought that you and Aunt Libbie would
come with Uncle John this Summer. I looked for you last year.  I hope that Aunt is better and that you might see us once more now if she is alive and knows tell her that Father never knew of her & baby Altana's fall.  but Altana is all right  she is getting over the German measles. and she passed biology.

got the town spelling contest so the bump did not hurt her.    Well dear cousin if we are not so that we will meet in this world it may be a brighter and Happer one over their.

 Write or come just as you can as Ever you Cousins  Ray & Nellie.
 With much love to you from Altana. I took your letter down to Aunt Cora.

Chicago, Dec - 14 - 14[?]
Dear May -   Your lovely letter of condolence over the loss of my darling companion comes to me like the Balm of Gilead - No tribute to her could be any truer than yours -
none knew her better than you except me and only the most devoted lovers could know each other as we did. O, May it is this knowledge that is killing, every wakeful
minute of my life is of her and they are of misery and sorrow - I have had about one hour of surcease of sorrow only, it was a note of triumph that sounded - the only
one that will ever give me happiness - it was that she selected me to love above all else and cared more for my love than that of any other - but my heart is too burdened to sustain this note for long - Truly you are our dearest friend and we Confided & Connseled with you about our joys & sorrows - crossed out  no, only troubles - for all of these you gave that sweet sympathy that only profound love and friendship can feel - My information was that she was only dangerously ill & much as I feared the worst I did not give up hope until I reached home - My first thought was of my promise to you that you and I should care for her until the end - as the hours sped by this thought was all interwoven of how we would do it.  I wrote you a little note

while her dear body was yet unburied - but had not found your address and I am so weakened  could not seek it as of old - Mrs Allen, Miss Bingham, Mr Dixon & Mrs Crump wer with her all of her consious moments - She was stricken just as she and Mrs Allen were going to dine at the Rosalie Inn - they all say she met it bravely and, sent just one message to me - "to go on and live my life" & she was so beautiful they all say - But May there is not enough left in life for me to want to go on. I try to be brave but all Philosophy breaks down in a time like this, only a powerful love could have stood the storms & stress we had but we did love so deeply. The last three months I had lived in her little apartment with her and we did have such a sweet time - we used to speak so often of you and May our life seemed even richer & fuller than ever - I know none will miss her more than you & I trust some day I can see you & tell you more about her, my feelings compel me to say good bye for the present -

  Your ever fond Comrade
    HRH Crump

                                                                    Sept. 18, 1927

My dear Friend:-

 A letter from Stella a few weeks ago told me of the loss you have sustained in the death of your dear Mother; and it has been in my heart

ever since to write to try to tell you how sorry I am. But my own Mother has been quite ill; and my time has been much divided between her and the
cousin in Cheshire whom I am supposed to be caring for this summer.

 Fortunately she is so much better that a cousin across the street is looking after her.

Mother is gaining strength, but so slowly that she sometimes finds it discouraging; but she is a most patient patient.

 I am not at all sure whether you are back in Avon Park in the little house you so lovingly prepared for the dear Mother, and which

she so enjoyed as long as she was spared to it.  I am glad it was sanctified by her enjoyment for a little while. Her thought and her
influence remain in it, else you would not miss her bodily presence so. One of the proofs - if we need proofs - of the eternity of the loves that
God gives into our earthly lives, is the abiding of that love after the separation of the earthly presence. I love to know

that these days on earth are a part of the beautiful eternity God plans for us - that it is all one life; we only know this little section of it, and that not so
very well; but He sees its relation to the whole beautiful pattern; it is all one.

 We will soon be returning to Avon Park - I think, on Mother's account, a little earlier than usual this year; and we shall hope to see you there.
      Sincerely,
      Alice S. Davidson

May L Davis (cousin of Katherine Kerr Moore) to K.K.M.

    May 16, 1930

My dear Katharine:

 We were indeed surprised when Starr & Maggie brot up your first letter to them - and I thot perhaps when you found out that I was still alive you might write to me.
 Think I am quite as well as when you saw me last. It seems a long time ago. And my precious mother and father have gone home, the house that they last occupied to-gether burned, and Joe [^ Starr's oldest son] & his wife have a new house on the dear old farm. But the old house I used to live in still stands.    
 I was sorry to hear of

your Uncle Jim's death.  Had heard nothing from him since he came for a day after your grandfather's death.

 We will be glad to have you come out to see us. Cannot your husband & boys come, too? You will find many changes in people & places, but we would try to give you a good time.   Have you a car? And would you drive, or come on the train, or bus?

We could meet you at Cherry Valley. Yes, Roscoe was our dog, and I well remember Manilla & Dewey!

 We shall have many things to talk of -

Thank you for the picture of yourself - I can see a resemblance to the girl of my memory.

 Let us know when you can come.
     With love -
       May L. Davis.

May 20,'35.

 Dear Katharine:
    Managed to get the chain letters off the next day after receiving the one from you. Had one from Annetta the same day.  I have little faith in them & don't suppose you or your mother have either.
 Was glad to hear from you tho and hope to see you this summer some day -
 Isn't it nice not to have the heat & dust of last May? Of course we could stand more sunshine, but things grow - The country looks so green & fresh -  Have finished planting corn -   The garden is much farther

2.

along than usual. Cherry & apple trees in full bloom.

 A few weeks ago we had a cousin with her two boys, 4 1/2 & 2 yrs. of age here for several days. And tho they were strenuous days, they were also happy ones.  Do you remember meeting Cousin Thane Brown Sr., Thane Jr. and their cousin & housekeeper, Cousin Alice Brown here some summers ago?  Well, this was Cousin Thane Sr. daughter Helen - it is the first time she has been here since her marriage. She has hair much like yours & is about your size. I called her "Katharine" several times. She is a little younger than Annetta.  Her father died last July and the

3.

family scattered - Cousin Alice gone to Oxford, Ohio her old home town.  Helen's brother Thane is in a CCC camp in northern Wis. at the head of a company of boys. He graduated as an engineer two years ago.

 Starr is having his teeth out & we hope he will improve faster when that is over with.  
 By the way, has anyone written of the two new babies in the Lyford family!  Emily's boy, born April 24, and Franklin's boy - just two weeks later.  John Lyle and Franklin Starr -  All home from the hospital & doing fine.

Annetta is busy helping her father & babies too. She goes to see them quite often. Emily has been home several times - They have found

4.

out the baby likes to ride, so when he cries she puts him in the car and he stops as soon as they get going!  Marian & Joan, also Martha & children have had the German measles - and Martha had to have her tonsils out, & has had neuritis since, but is much better.  Has good help.   Dicky was caught in the fence one day & his dog ran barking to Martha until she went with him & found & rescued the child.

 Remember me to May & the boys - and come to see us some day.      With love -
               May L.D.

11 of July 1926

My dear May

 It is very wet and cold up in these regions. How is it where you are? Rob is in bed sick. Has been running down for a long time  The Dr. thinks he will get the

better of his troubles, tho he looks and has the same symptoms as his brother Howard whom I nursed and he died in this good old home years ago. This place
has been the house for many a weary soul who has gone with the Angels, blessed be the giver, a little paper giving notice of the passing of your dear Mother in
Matamora Ill Herald & save the item. How wonderful that I am spared while others not as old have gone, one other who reminded me of your Ma has passed away

well my time of course is limited yet I cling to this life as I know where I am now and who knows about the beyond _

 I want to know about what you are doing. If you are rested and all right, Now take a rest sufficient 'tho not too much as it may possibly

be that your old harness may not fit and you will have to be refitted but dont take to the aeroplanes    Dear May  God bless you your ideals must
hold you and the same will eventually unite you and I.    lovingly

  L. A. Fairbanks

6th of July 1927
My dear dear May -

 Well she has gone from your sight leaving a lonesomeness but a blessed thankfulness that you were able to be with her thru it all, that she could be in her old home among old friends on those lovely Mts. A ray of light opens up to my dulled vision thru the perusal of Swedenborgs writings making the future more of a reality. A living world, a resting place and also a place where our highest ideals may be realised, Ideals, Ideals the only God we know and love, I've listened to yours. your God, Mine also, only to be conscious of it, makes the light,

but enough of this, you are a grand Christian woman and must not falter, you are one of the salt of the earth only you must know and realize your greatness -   This marks a change, What will you do? will you go back to A.P. and make that your staying place?  I am in the old home still too lame to go far yet there seems to be a need of me here so many dependent on my help, I seem also able to fill the place, Rob is poorly but we could not fill his place and must try to get along.   The boys do well, now is their vacation  Francis has

another year before graduation  He has had the misfortune of breaking a bone in his hand which puts him back somewhat  Sybil is doing well  helps her Ma, I'm left about alone
with much work tho I can cook  I can do but little in the way of anything more, Do not ride much as my back suffers when I do, The days are lovely now 'tho we have had many cold rainy ones when a fire has been necessary to my comfort and we have kept 2 agoing

 With dearest love and I only wish I could be of use to you in some way at any rate I love you My dear good May   Robert joins me
                         L.A. Fairbanks

Haven't seen Bertha)

Dear Mrs Walden

 The Metamora paper came today, so I learned that you too are alone, for I think it is only with a mother's passing that one learns what it is to be alone.

It must be a comfort to you that you could be with her and care for her in your pleasant home for so long - I had not realized how old she was.

 My only comfort has been the thought of

my mother's joy at meeting her father again, and I believe that and the thought of the reunion when one's own time comes, is the only help there is in grief like this.

 With all love and sympathy -
   Sincerely
  Eleanor Farrar

Amy

                   948 Cowper St.
                   Palo Alto, Calif.  4/19/27

My Dear Nora -,

 Were you in any European nook or cranny, I could in a general way visualize the setting you are in - But try as I will, no picture comes to my mind of "Nora in Algiers" -

It is as nebulous a dream as "Nora in Heaven" - Yet I suspect, you feel more "of the earth, earthy" there, than any place you have ever abided. All this shows, that after all, much of life is in the mind - Life is big or little, confused or clear, important or unimportant, according to the picture the mind holds. I find that mentally living through my European trip, gives me greater pleasure, than did the reality. And too, I have discovered, that only the people who have travelled the same roads, can appreciate, even understand, what I am patiently trying to tell, for only those who have seen have mental pictures -

 How big your world will be when you return to us! For I feel, your ambitions will be satisfied with nothing less, than circumscribing the globe - which once to you was the choicest gift,  Life had to offer!  Now ? it is being accomplished!  "Nora in Africa". Really that sounds like a phrase out of a fairy tale - or a wonderful romance! Wonderful! Wonderful! And more wonderful, when the mind fastens itself upon the limited bank account on which it was accomplished - and most wonderful still - with all the other handicaps

is your determination in the face of your state of health. You are a lady of courage! I doff my hat to you in appreciation of your accomplishments in spite of what all but the
brave crossed out: few and determined few would consider, insurmountable obstacles - But you were always so. The wildest chorus of "Nay, nays," never fazed you, when your heart and mind championed a purpose - Your motto blazed forth in letters of fire - "Do or Die!"

 I do not remember when I last wrote, but know that Hattie has been sending my letters on to you, so that you are quite in touch with my activities, as I am with yours, because she shares your letters with many of us here.  At times, I request her not to send special letters to any one, but she is incorrigible on that score. for she does it anyway, just as you send Editha's letter to us.  Of course, there were no state secrets in Editha's letter, such as I sometimes put into mine.
 It is a habit of Editha's it seems, as her letters to me contain the same request -  I so hope you two will meet soon along the Riviera - Dont feel offended, if Editha sort of keeps to herself - It is her tired mood, that will disappear, when she recovers from her weariness -    Her sister Louise has been in Los Angeles this winter - Editha wrote me to write her to come up to Palo Alto, which I did. She'll be here the middle of May. Editha once brought her up to our Chicago Warner Ave. home about ten years ago - for dinner one

evening -   The two sisters are very different - Louise said to Mother that evening - "You and I would get on charmingly, Mrs. Pischel - as neither claims to be a  high-brow"

Only yesterday I sent Editha a letter, including her sister's note to me, in which she announced her visit to us.

 Mother & I are seriously discussing plans for our departure from Palo Alto. The climate here does not agree with Mother - and she wishes to get away. To where, we have

not yet decided - but probably to the southern part of California - We are going down to visit Los Angeles and San Diego soon, and will them make up our minds.   I am
leaving the decision to Mother - for these are her years. I am alarmed at the change these seven months in Palo Alto have brought! But she is four score and one years - Perhaps it is just the mark of time, not the climate or even loneliness - It wall makes me very sad.

 You too, my dear know the loneliness that consumes me - when the loved ones have passed on - and now your brother has joined the group!  How rapidly our ranks are

thinning! For them, I have no sighs, even if Death means a sleep from which one do not awaken. I know you are sure, we do awaken. But whether or not we do, Death seems a great  friend to me - To go yang? and quickly is my fervent prayer. It was so, Gus went, so that in Death at least, he was among the fortunate. As I wrote Hattie, I hoped she would not grieve for him - or regret anything. Even if one is so philosophical, I know only too well, the tragic loneliness that descents upon one. And it does not mean? away. Perhaps for the young it may - but not at our age.

 I wish I could say something that might make the sorrow easier to hear. I feel helpless in doing so.

on side, in different ink:
Amy: This refers to the death of my brother. you know, however, that I consider death but a door into a larger life, Nora.
When you come I'll let you read my answer to Emma, kept a copy - don't want to send it to my climr?ys?

on left side:  [Enclosed with letter from Amy]
Yet I know, a message from friends is comforting. I am sorry, the time will be so long, before this reaches you. If there is anything I can do, will you not command one?  Just know it will be a pleasure to do it.

 I have asked Hattie to come up to see us. I need her comfort too as the winter has been a trying one in many ways. Guiding two young boys. I have found is not exactly a party. I am glad the year is almost at an end - I shall be as happy to see the boys depart for home, as I will be to greet them next fall upon their return.
 My plan was to do some studying myself - but I have failed to do it - I find with Mother, the boys and their friends on week-ends, our own visitors and all the house keeping,

there is little of the day left. Personally I should be glad to stay on for a few years here, until the boys are through school. Palo Alto is rather a pleasant place, quiet and pretty, with opportunities of a college town, and the added advantage of its proximity to "the City" as San Francisco is called by the peninsula folks. It is to San Francisco, what Evanston is to Chicago - Of course Palo Alto is not as large as Evanston.

 There I do choose a place. I think I should return to Chicago - I was very happy there last summer, and have the feeling that I shall always think of it as "home". There are so many folks there I really love - and life for me was at its Peak there.
 Please when you write, will you send me Mrs. Felt's address. Send it in Hatties letter. Should you write Mrs. F. soon, wont you send her my address, and tell her to drop me a

line.  It was good to see Robert when he was playing in "The Don" in S.F.    Love and good wishes in abundance to you -  ? -   E_ _a  Pischel

March 7 [1930]

Tribe Katerina,

 I felt so sure of getting a note off to you before we moved, but I didn't, and here we are in Western Springs.  Moved last Saturday and I celebrated by going right to bed and being sick for four days. Aus had to go to Cedar Rapids in the midst of it for several days and now the baby is sick so we are far from being settled.
 Aunt Carrie has been with us since her return from Florida the 13th of January. I'm hoping to keep her until we are all settled.
 Before we moved we tried to get some of the sewing done.  Made Aus seven shirts, the girls

dresses and pajamas. Have loads more to do. You've no idea how busy I am with my four girls!

 We've a nice place here - large house and a lot the size Grossmutter's was, with shade and fruit trees. The yard has been neglected, tho, and will need lots

of work to get in shape.

 Was so sorry your mother went back without my seeing her. Better luck next time!
 And now - I'm really ashamed to tell it, but I haven't read the book yet! With Aunt Carrie here there's no time for loafing!  I love having it around tho, knowing

that it's there waiting for me. It's the first book I've ever had that I didn't read right away. That's the penalty for having so many babies!

 Much love,
    Margarita

Dear Comrade Kerr:

 I was rejoiced to read about the proposed new "Socialist Temple" in the "Workers Call." It is a noble and Grave undertaking.  I hope the

New York Comrades will do the same. My wife and I feel we must have some fellowship with the

Chicago comrades in this matter, and I am sure they will not deny us the privilege. So I enclose you $100 from us for the
"Temple" fund.

 We are living in a little Swiss Village, on the Italian side of the Mountains, and gain-

ing rest and strength for the work before us. My Throat is getting well again, and I hope to be in good speaking condition before Spring.

  With loving greetings from both of us to Mrs. Kerr and yourself.
     Faithfully Yours
         George D. Herron

Dec 18/1906

 My Dear Mr. Kerr,
  I mail my Christmas greeting to you early, because near the holidays the mail  delivery usually becomes very irregular & I would rather have you get this a day or two early, than too late.
 I read & thank you very much for your kind answer to my enquiry about theFitch? publication. I have also received the printed matter you mentioned & perused it with much interest.
 I am now past the allotted 3 score & ten, but I cherish the memory of yourself & wife, as lovers of humanity among the brightest & warmest recollections of a long & eventful life.
 For a number of years, I have at Christmas evidenced my affectionate remembrance to a small circle of friends, by a few lines of doggerell of which the enclosed are a sample & which they appreciate, not because the lines are worthy of it, but because they feel kindly towards the writer.
 This year I have ventured to include you & Mrs. K. in this circle. Please forward the verses to Mrs. K. & please read them yourself for they will show you, my attitude towards Socialism.
 I am in full accord & sympathy with the ideals & with the theory of socialism & with its propoganda. I believe in universal voluntary cooperation & in public ownership of the resources of nature & means of production. But I have no use for the Socialist ?prognosis?, which proposes coercion by violence if necessary of the minority, by a majority, even if it be but of one vote.
 I believe such a majority, if suddenly placed in control of all political

& economic power, would be more arbitrary, & despotic, then any government humanity has been obliged to  witness, these many centuries.  I am well aware, that such is not the theory. But untested theories of government, are no more reliable, than haphazard conjectures. There could hardly be a theory of government designed more favorably for the governed, than that of the U.S. & see into what a corrupt plutocratic despotism it has worked out! See NB at bottom of page.

 Socialism, like freemasonry & religion must first be established in the hearts of people, after that it will need no coercion, will be carried on by voluntary cooperation.
 I believe you & I & all who long for the universal rule of justice, will have to be patient, for many, many generations, while natural selection is slowly preparing our race for its higher destiny. In the meantime municipal ownership may have to run its fitfull course of slow advances & sudden retrogressions, the same as all progress. We are the products of the Universe & while intelligence, industry & cooperation can modify our environment, we are yet largely subject to it. -
 I hope to hear from you, in answer to this & to the rhymes.
 With best wishes & cordial regards to yourself & Mrs K.
                     Sincerely Your
                     T.W. Heineman

NB. So long as government is sustained, by the organized means for wholesale assassination, so long as the vast majority admire & desire to imitate successful plunderers, & hold in contempt the financially unsuccessful person of high moral ideals, displayed in conduct rather than profession, so long it will be unsafe to add so enormously to administrative power, as the socialist theory even would demand & those in power can always evade the logical outcome of any theory, if they have but the character for evasion.

849 Lincoln Avenue
Pasadena, Cal.

Dec 20/06
  With cordial regards & best wishes for the health & happiness of Mrs & Mr Kerr
         from   T W Heineman

Dear May.  Your letter came & I cant tell you how much more it meant than the card that I sent you - but I did hope to find time to write you later. Today the folks are gone to Church & I was too tired to go so I dont know hoe better I could employ my time than chatting with you. While I write Dr White is preaching & it is as tho he were right in the room. The Radio is wonderful. I may get bits of his sermon in this letter. I do appreciate the dilemma in having to listen to an old moss back preacher - who hasnt found out

that the flood is over - I think you will do well to turn to the great minds offered in books &c  but dont withdraw your support from an institution that at least is spiritual in the community  tho what is taught is mostly wrong. It still is a stepping stone to spiritual life - for many who havnt come along as far in thought as you have.  it is a great joy to find kindred spirits but I find them rare  I have spells when I want to run away from the commonplace but God no doubt loved the commonplace for he made so many people in that stripe.  I know that I too am commonplace in spots but my soul has had a vision

My dear May,

 Cousin Mollie sent us a clipping telling of your good Mothers passing  We were greatly surprised. The last we heard of her, she was in excellent health. I want to express to you our love and sympathy for we know what a large space in our lives, is empty  When Mother goes = You have been most fortunate to have kept her so long with you.

The passing leaves Mrs Wikoff the last of that generation - The Whitmires  the Briggs, Cassells - Bassetts, Earls & many other we knew in our youth have all joined the silent 
majority

and leave their children  the old folks - sometimes When I look back I feel a thousand years old - So much, that is uneventful to be sure, has passed, But that is the way of life,
go we must, rank after rank. - & ours is now in step on the march. -  I am not one who looks with dread & disapproval. It all depends on ones point of view - I mean to
accept the inevitable without a struggle  When you find time I wish you would write us the particulars -   I hope you are well and your own self  The girls join me in love & sympathy.

  Sincerely,
    Marie J Hesse

Darling K -

  So sorry, and still wouldn't it have been sad to have that useful, efficient soul burdened with earth's

infirmities any longer? I am sure she is finding those dear hills just as delightful in her new garment, and
no doubt in the company of her kindred spirits.

 How staunch and true she stood beside her standard. It wasn't a standard of middle courses or

 Just this for to-night dear K. and will write again to Mother.     Helen

Dec 28, '39.
Dear, beautiful Taffern,

 I received your cunning card and was so glad to hear from you. I am enclosing a beautiful scene

which I know you will like to look at.  I just adore snow, and as we seem short of it this Christmas,
there is nothing to do but to look at a lovely picture like this one.

 Did you have a nice Christmas? I was fortunate this year. The children

are all well and the boys are working, both at Crane Co.

 My cousin Mrs. Gartz was very good to us all.
 I finally put my pride in my pocket, along with my scotch

thistles and called my aunt in Elgin. She was civil, which is more than
I hoped for, so I did not regret calling her.

 How is your wonderful Mother?  I think it is amazing how she keeps up

with the march of Time.

 We have a nice young priest here for a few weeks, he is substituting for the regular pastor who

is basking in the sunny south, after a very active campaign to raise funds for a new church.

 This new priest looks just like Malcolm, and is very pleasant.  By the way, how are the boys?

Has Malcolm's family increased? Well
