newspaper clipping:
Rev. J.B. Blake, Pastor for Forty Years, Is Dead

 The Rev. James Vila Blake, 83 years old, a Unitarian

minister for forty years, died yesterday at his home, 
122 Ashland Boulevard.  He was pastor of the Third
Unitarian church here for fifteen years and was head of
the All Souls church in Evanston from 1892-1911. Mr. Blake
graduated from Harvard in 1862 and then became secretary
to the governor of Massachusetts. Later he went into the
ministry. He leaves two daughters, Ruth Blake and Mrs. Rachel
Mahoney, both of whom live in Mexico. A son, Clifton F. lives in
Portland, O.

       122 N. Ashland Bovl,
          May 6, 1925

Dear Mrs. Walden,

 Probably you have heard that our friend is gone.
 It was a fight of many weeks, but was not known to be serious until too late. There

was an infection of the neck, eventuating in cancer.   You will be glad to know the later
weeks were practically free from pain, and that he kept all his vigorous faculties.

 The passing was peaceful and beautiful as befitted him.
    With kindest regards
     C. Amelia Hughes -

"Ski Ho"
Calif. Hot Springs, Calif.

 July 17, 1926.

Dear May Walden,

 I am enclosing a circular just gotten out by the J.V.B. Association.

It would have come to you anyway as a member, but I asked to add a personal
word. Probably no one else of the friends knows so well of your long faithful
friendship and devotion.

 I feel quite sure you will favor such a memorial, but you may feel that even a small 

contribution is not in your providence. If so, we are glad of the

moral support of your approval, and count you with us just as heartily as your long faithfulness to our friend deserves.

 Would that you could be one of the near-by intimates of the little group at the helm! I think it would cheer your

sympathetic heart.

 Early in July I cane west to my cabin here in the Sequoia Gov. Reserve and I will remain through the month, going

to Long Beach, Cal. then for the

rest of the summer. My sister's address there: 121 Grand Ave., will always
reach me.

 The vacation spirit holds me in a pretty close grip, and the amount of lounging agreeable is incredible.
 Such "murmurous woods - aisles" here, and the small animal life is full of interest and sociability.

My best wishes to you for a happy summer

  Most sincerely,
   C. Amelia Hughes

Calif. Hot Springs
Tulare Co. Calif.

Office - Room 560
17 N. La Salle St. Chicago

April 13, 1927.

My dear Mrs. Walden.

 I venture to write you once more of the tablet to Mr. Blake. It is nearing completion,

and the fund for it is practically closed. But there are still a few friends whom we wish to feel
are associated with this memorial testimony, and you are one of these.  Do you
not wish now to contribute a dollar, and feel always that you had a part with us in this?
The tablet is a bas-relief portrait bust with inscriptions at both sides.

The little picture you sent was excellent and would probably enlarge well. The bust was
taken from later pictures and very satisfying to those of us who knew him only in those
later years. No doubt one of mid-age wd. appeal to the earlier friends.

 Your letter reached me last summer at Long Beach.  I hope you will forgive my long

silence, for my most treasured correspondence has all been "thrown to the winds", in

an endeavor to bring some kind of ordered re-adjustment to the effects of our
vanished friend.

 I shall always welcome any word from you.   I hope life deals sunnily with

you in all ways.

  Most sincerely,
  C. Amelia Hughes

Aug 23-'/07
My dear Mrs Kerr,

 I also had a letter from Patty, but you see she tell's me nothing. I have

posted her today taking no notice of your's - and expressed my surprise
at her alluding to your house as ours. I hope sincerely she May be
happy, but I have my doubts.   What a lovely country yours must be!
The P.C. of Miver? is beautiful.  Many thanks - I must remember
Katharine's album.  So glad to hear you are all well. It

must be very hard to decide what is best to be done, I fear my verdict would be: study K -, health first she can
learn extra's after -  No doubt you miss many things in the country but think of the freedom - I have not yet received
your manuscript. I trust its not lost, do ask your friend about it. I very much enjoyed The Golden Girl. Have not done any
reading lately, 16th of last month, I had a wire from a friend saying she was taking charge of two little boys, and would
I look for rooms for her?  Well I said they could stay here until they looked themselves. After a few days the boy aged 12 was not well, 
& couldn't make it out. he complained of his head - well it ended in his Mother (was is a trained nurse) coming on the 25, When the
s?? boy, and Miss G - had to turn into room's[?]

and the Nurse for night duty. Dr. three? times a day - Not a sound to be made in the house - but it ended most peacefully Aug 8th  Unconscious two
days. "Meningitis"  So you may guess what a time it's been, fortunately we have not had very hot weather. But now I am feeling the strain and don't
feel up to much just got garden, hardly been looked at. You seem to have all things we have, only in greater quantity I suspect. this soil is so sandy -
required such a quantity of manure, and I have to pay 6/6 a load.  We have no Azalias, or Rhododendrons. Only in grand gardens here.  No
tomatoes hardly this year. We have had so little sun - lots of rain

a few blackberries about in the hedges latter, that all we have about here. I fear you would dispise this country after yours - very little of the
Stalion blue this summer  Now I had better leave off, or you will say what an old grumbler -   I sent Pattie a lace? affair - and will you and K-
please accept - enclosed too late for her birthday, perhaps in time for yours, which I wish you Many happy returns -
With very much love, and best wishes to you all -

  Ever yours affectality
    Jenny Ingham

I wish the Herring pond, didn't divide us -

Albert Villa

Oct 20th/07
My dear Mrs Kerr

 I was very pleased to receive your letter - It had occurred to me that you

might be on the wing - No doubt you were sorry to leave your old home and will miss the
lovely scenery - City life is very

tiring I think. I hope Katharine likes her school - And that you have found something to do
that you like, for I guess you are not one to sit still - You must have been lucky in your apartments, seems to me
very cheap. So it right for your tenants to run up bill; for you to pay? without your consent? but? not they
to pay if they ordered - I think it would be so here -   If you clean the lace yourself, I should get good
soapy water, and pat it well between hand's in it - iron between paper - but here we send any

-thing particular to the cleaners - I read once ribbon and lace was very expensive in America. It is so?
I would much like if you would send me your pamphlet - I think it horrid of people to retain things lent -
for such a long time - I have heard no more from Pattie. Certainly I should not allow K - to go out with her - My old school fellow 
crossed the bar on the 10th  I am so thankful the poor dear is out of her suffering. I did not go to the funeral. Not feeling
equal to the long journey. And the strain. besides could do no good - Pollis? was her bird

but she said I was to keep it. his great company - This is such a quiet life - I am too lazy to make friends - we have had such a lot of rain lately,
the garden looks so untidy, the plants are not up yet - I dread a frost coming before they are - Hope we shall not have a severe winter -
Cold nips me up - Its so changable here, Makes it more trying I think.  There seems nothing fresh to tell you dear Mrs Kerr.
With much love to yourself and K -

  Yours affecately
    Jenny Ingham

Dec 8th/07

My dear Mrs-Kerr
 This morning I received A White Hyacinth* just had a peep inside, it seems to contain good advice. The binding also is

so quaint, I have never seen any like it, altogether a most charming book, but who is the owner? anyhow, until I hear,
it will be greatly prized, and well cared for. Now you Most dear person. I should like to show your M.S. to a
[*Note:  probably the book by Elbert Hubbard, 1907]

friend should he happen to come this way at Xmas, so will venture to keep it until the New Year -
What a host of things to look up - But I doubt us ever arriving at equality - If only there could
be no distressing poverty -but when one thinks of my brother's abilities (he alway's seemed in
poverty) careless folks must go to the wall - actions, proves more than words, of which he had
plenty - You did not send "The Socialist woman." It will be nice for you amongst friends you seem
to be having a busy time. dont overdo it. The rent

seems small - hope you will have the bother of another move -  Katharine will be looking forward
to her holidays I expect - She will not have any chicks to look after in the City. My first pullets egg today
What terrible weather we have had lately, so much rain, and fog - one day cold, next quite warm -
it's not healthy - So many colds about - so far I am fairly well.  I have not heard anymore from Pattie,
its useless waiting until one can make sure of her address. I  must send poor Katie a line, I am sorry
for the poor thing, she seemed

quite cast away. How hard life is to so many -    9th - It's so difficult to know what trifle will be useful - for I
expect you will have everything we have. So please accept these, one for K - with my very best wishes for the Season -

 Much love   from Yours affectally
       Jenny Ingham

My dear Mrs Kerr.

 I am quite ashamed at not answering your's of Dec 22d before this, although

I am not a busy woman like you, somehow, time slips away, more quickly the 
older one grows I think.  Thanks for letting me keep your M.S. - My friend Who I wanted

to see it has not yet turned up - I so wonder how you are getting on, of course you see
how the Suffratgettes are working in London. What will be the end I wonder! After all, home
is a woman place.  'White Hyacinth' lies on my table beside me always to take up and find
interest in. What charming people they must be - I was so sorry about Katharine's illness,
it would be rather awkward for you, wasn't it?

?at?iss? her father - 'but I hope you are all well now. Did you go to Glen Ellyn at Xmas?  I haven't heard anything from
Pattie beyond receiving an illustrated H?gonn? at that time. So perhaps she turned Saint. The other poor thing (Katie)
seems quite devoted to her children, her's seems a hard life -  I have just had a week in bed with influenza, no pain,
only so weak, and good for nothing, but am on the mend -   Weather still so changable -  We have had so much fog -
but one comfort - the severe

cold is over, for the poor people who are without work, one reads of distress all over the world -
The snow drops, violets, and primroses are coming out. What a pity you live so far away -  My 
Pollis? is still flourishing, his last saying is "The Top of the Morning" - I have no dog or cat
now - still keep a few fowls, I often think of K-s interest in her sitting hen -  Rats are my plague

 I long to hear about your writings;  trusting all is well with you both
 With much love
   Ever yours affecatety
     Jenny Ingham

Elm Villa
Hayling Island
Hants
July 16th 1908
Dear Mrs Kerr.

 You will be wondering what on earth has happened to me - Of course I had intended written long ago - but really I

do not know what the last seven weeks have been like - I was in the garden, and had a sting, it swelled but I did
not think anything of that

until the end of the week when my throat seemed closing, so sent for the Dr - who has been
attending me since. I have been in my bed now all the time, he said it was an abcess, anyhow
all the hot poultices etc. took no effect, it was like a great lump of iron on my neck. so just a
fortnight ago they operated, and the would is quite healed but still very swollen. The Dr. said
I must go to the sea at once, so on Tuesday I came here, and am already feeling stronger.
hope to remain a fortnight - unprtand? July the weather is very showery. The month of
June was lovely, but I did not care to look out of

the window even. I know your birthday is sometime now (but cannot tell until I look at home)  Anyhow, I hope you will accept
my very best wishes. I so hope you are getting on well with your pupils - ect - Suppose holiday time will soon come. I have
not heard again from Pattie; do you ever hear anything of her?  Now I have told you all my happenings. so will not
bother you longer -

Everything seems a trouble to me yet -  With much love to you both dear Mrs Kerr -
Hoping you are in good health      Ever yours affecately

                      Jenny Ingham

Sept 9th/08
My dear Mrs Kerr

 Many thanks for your letter, with enclosures. I am not at all

shocked at you speaking in the streets, if only it will help the
poor people in any way - but I dont like to hear of strikes, it
seems to me - better to half a loaf, than no

bread especially in the cold weather - Trust you will not meet with any disturbance.
Dont get marched off to prison, like a good many over here. Fear you will not make
money over it. Yours must indeed be a busy life - Its nice K - is doing so well at
School.  Pattie seems a queer girl! I had a few lines from her, Gaizing? her sister
was dead and begging me to write to her husband some

consolation! fancy I dont know the Man - A few days ago came a P.C. from your niece
(which she is not) Pattie, and her address -  by the view it must be a pretty place - Have just sent
her a few lines, wondering what she is doing - Nothing fit to speak of I fear -  Why I thought her
sister was married ages ago - Was this a second marriage?   We are having very stormy weather
blowing the fruit off the trees, till I fear

there will not be any apples to store for the winter - May he a?? is much as usual again -
Trusting you both are well.    With much love

  Ever yours affectely
      Jenny Ingham
